description: This course is an introduction to the basic concepts and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Several important concepts will be studied in detail, including: revenue recognition, inventory, long-lived assets, present value, and long term liabilities. The course emphasizes the construction of the basic financial accounting statements - the income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement - as well as their interpretation.
name: PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTING

values.comments:
This course is an introduction to the basic concepts and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Several important concepts will be studied in detail, including: revenue recognition, inventory, long-lived assets, present value, and long-term liabilities. The course emphasizes the construction of the basic financial accounting statements - the income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement - as well as their interpretation. 

Overall, students agreed that this course was “useful” and “well-structured”, though often boring. Despite lectures that “were not particularly stimulating”, students acknowledged that the lecture was a “core class” and a requirement for business students. Many students commented that the lecture material coincided entirely with the assigned textbook readings. 

Students appreciated Professor Balakrishnan’s enthusiasm for the course material, accessibility to students seeking help, and overall ability to clearly communicate the subject matter. Students further praised Professor Balakrishnan’s organization and “helpful” lecture slides. One student called Professor Balakrishnan an “excellent professor”. Another student commented that Professor Balakrishnan “spends classroom time on seemingly unimportant and easy concepts while going quickly through what is hard and important.” Overall, however, students agreed that Professor Balakrishnan presented the lecture material in a coherent and organized way that made it easier to understand, as well as engaging “through interesting examples and real world applications of concepts.”

Many of the students in this course complained that, though the material was not especially difficult, the course “requires a lot of work.” Students agreed that while the homework was fair, the exams were “tough.” Students disliked the multiple-choice format of the exams, as they felt the tests did not accurately assess student comprehension. Students commented that they would have appreciated a “more appropriate exam format” for “math-based classes” like this one.

This course is an introduction to the basic concepts and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Several important concepts will be studied in detail, including: revenue recognition, inventory, long-lived assets, present value, and long term liabilities. The course emphasizes the construction of the basic financial accounting statements - the income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement - as well as their interpretation. 

Students were divided in their opinions of this course. One reviewer described the class as “a thorough, albeit dry, introduction to accounting.” Others credited the professor with “making a boring subject interesting” and were “continually impressed with how he kept the subject relevant.” 

Comments about Professor Taylor were generally positive, but several students disliked his habit of “cold-calling” during class. 

The course material was described as not particularly interesting, but made more so by the professor. Several reviewers, however, criticized the multiple-choice exams as “unfair” and “not always completely representative of students’ abilities.”
